column1: ap 08:00|"eight o’clock"|"Harris said he thought it would be humpy. He said he knew the sort of place I meant; where everybody went to bed at eight o’clock
column2: and you couldn’t get a Referee1 for love or money
column3: and had to walk ten miles to get your baccy."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"The steward recommended the latter course
column2: as it would come so much cheaper. He said they would do him for the whole week at two-pounds-five. He said for breakfast there would be fish
column3: followed by a grill. Lunch was at one
column4: and consisted of four courses. Dinner at six – soup
column5: fish
column6: entrée
column7: joint
column12: and dessert. And a light meat supper at ten."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column5: fish
column6: entrée
column7: joint
column12: and dessert. And a light meat supper at ten."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"At six
column2: they came and told him dinner was ready. Thean nouncement aroused no enthusiasm within him
column3: but he felt that there was some of that two-pounds-five to be worked off
column4: and he held on to ropes and things and went down. A pleasant odour of onions and hot ham
column5: mingled with fried fish and greens
column6: greeted him at the bottom of the ladder; and then the steward came up with an oily smile
column7: and said:"|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ~ 00:00|"about midnight"|"Then we had to find the rule and the string again
column2: and a new hole was made; and
column3: about midnight
column4: the picture would be up – very crooked and insecure
column5: the wall for yards round looking as if it had been smoothed down with a rake
column6: and everybody dead beat and wretched – except Uncle Podger."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"At the end of that trip we met together at midnight in a lonely field
column2: under a blasted oak
column3: and took an awful oath (we had been swearing for a whole week about the thing in an ordinary
column4: middle-class way
column5: but this was a swell affair) – an awful oath never to take paraffin oil with us in a boat again – except
column6: of course
column7: in case of sickness."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 07:00|seven|"‘We shan’t want any tea
column2: ’ said George (Harris’s face fell at this); ‘but we’ll have a good round
column3: square
column4: slap-up meal at seven – dinner
column5: tea
column6: and supper combined.’"|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 22:05|"10.5 p.m."|"When I had finished
column2: George asked if the soap was in. I said I didn’t care a hang whether the soap was in or whether it wasn’ t; and I slammed the bag to and strapped it
column3: and found that I had packed my tobacco pouch in it
column4: and had to reopen it. It got shut up finally at 10.5 p.m.
column5: and then there remained the hampers to do. Harris said that we should be wanting to start in less than twelve hours’ time and thought that he and George had better do the rest; and I agreed and sat down
column6: and they had a go."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 00:50|12.50|"The packing was done at 12.50; and Harris sat on the big hamper
column2: and said he hoped nothing would be found broken. George said that if anything was broken it was broken
column3: which reflection seemed to comfort him. He also said he was ready for bed. We were all ready for bed. Harris was to sleep with us that night
column4: and we went upstairs."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 06:30|"half past six"|"Harris and I had a bit of a row over it
column2: but at last split the difference
column3: and said half past six."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 06:30|"half past six"|"Harris and I had a bit of a row over it
column2: but at last split the difference
column3: and said half past six.

column1: ‘Wake us at 6.30
column2: George
column3: ’ we said.

column1: George made no answer
column2: and we found
column3: on going over
column4: that he had been asleep for some time; so we placed the bath where he could tumble into it on getting out in the morning
column5: and went to bed ourselves."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap < 09:00|"nearly nine o’clock"|"She said:
‘Do you know that it’s nearly nine o’clock
column2: sir?’

column1: ‘Nine o’ what?’ I cried
column2: starting up."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 09:00|"Nine o’clock"|"‘Nine o’clock
column2: ’ she replied
column3: through the keyhole. ‘I thought you was a-oversleeping yourselves.’"|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"I woke Harris
column2: and told him. He said:

column1: ‘I thought you wanted me to get up at six?’
‘So I did
column2: ’ I answered. ‘Why didn’t you wake me?’ he retorted. ‘Now we shan’t get on the water till after twelve. I wonder you take the trouble to get up at all.’"|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap > 00:00|"after twelve"|"I woke Harris
column2: and told him. He said:

column1: ‘I thought you wanted me to get up at six?’
‘So I did
column2: ’ I answered. ‘Why didn’t you wake me?’ he retorted. ‘Now we shan’t get on the water till after twelve. I wonder you take the trouble to get up at all.’"|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap > 00:00|"after twelve"|"‘So I did

column1: ap 09:45|"quarter to ten"|"‘Wassermarrer?’ he observed
column2: sitting up.

column1: ‘Get up
column2: you fat-headed chunk!’ roared Harris. ‘It’s quarter to ten.’

column1: ‘What!’ he shrieked
column2: jumping out of bed into the bath; ‘ – Who the thunder put this thing here?’"|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 00:00|"twelve o’clock"|"And we chuckled to think how wet they were going to get
column2: and came back and stirred the fire
column3: and got our books
column4: and arranged our specimens of seaweed and cockleshells. By twelve o’clock with the sun pouring into the room
column5: the heat became quite oppressive
column6: and we wondered when those heavy showers and occasional thunderstorms were going to begin."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 01:00|"one o’clock"|"At one o’clock the landlady would come in to ask if we weren’t going out
column2: as it seemed such a lovely day."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 10:00|"10 a.m."|"Then there are those new style of barometers
column2: the long straight ones. I never can make head or tail of those. There is one side for 10 a.m. yesterday
column3: and one side for 10 a.m. today; but you can’t always get there as early as ten
column4: you know. It rises or falls for rain and fine
column5: with much or less wind
column6: and one end is ‘Nly’ and the other ‘Ely’ (what’s Ely got to do with it?)
column7: and if you tap it
column8: it doesn’t tell you anything. And you’ve got to correct it to sea-level and reduce it to Fahrenheit
column9: and even then I don’t know the answer."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 11:00|eleven|"We got to Waterloo at eleven
column2: and asked where the eleven-five started from. Of course nobody knew; nobody at Waterloo ever does know where a train is going to start from
column3: or where a train when it does start is going to
column4: or anything about it. The porter who took our things thought it would go from number two platform
column5: while another porter
column6: with whom he discussed the question
column7: had heard a rumour that it would go from number one. The stationmaster
column9: was convinced it would start from the local."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 11:05|eleven-five|"We got to Waterloo at eleven
column2: and asked where the eleven-five started from. Of course nobody knew; nobody at Waterloo ever does know where a train is going to start from
column3: or where a train when it does start is going to
column4: or anything about it. The porter who took our things thought it would go from number two platform
column5: while another porter
column6: with whom he discussed the question
column7: had heard a rumour that it would go from number one. The stationmaster
column9: was convinced it would start from the local."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 09:32|9.32|"Then our porter said he thought that it must be it on the high-level platform; said he thought he knew the train. So we went to the high-level platform and saw the engine-driver
column2: and asked him if he was going to Kingston. He said he couldn’t say for certain of course
column3: but that he rather thought he was. Anyhow
column4: if he wasn’t the 11.5 for Kingston
column5: he said he was pretty confident he was the 9.32 for Virginia Water
column6: or the 10 a.m. express for the Isle of Wight
column7: or somewhere in that direction
column8: and we should all know when we got there. We slipped half-a-crown into his hand
column9: and begged him to be the 11.5 for Kingston."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 10:00|"10 a.m."|"Then our porter said he thought that it must be it on the high-level platform; said he thought he knew the train. So we went to the high-level platform and saw the engine-driver
column2: and asked him if he was going to Kingston. He said he couldn’t say for certain of course
column3: but that he rather thought he was. Anyhow
column4: if he wasn’t the 11.5 for Kingston
column5: he said he was pretty confident he was the 9.32 for Virginia Water
column6: or the 10 a.m. express for the Isle of Wight
column7: or somewhere in that direction
column8: and we should all know when we got there. We slipped half-a-crown into his hand
column9: and begged him to be the 11.5 for Kingston."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 05:00|"five o’clock"|"I reminded him of George
column2: and how we had to get the boat up to Shepperton by five o’clock to meet him
column3: and then he went for George. Why was George to fool about all day
column4: and leave us to lug this lumbering old top-heavy barge up and down the river by ourselves to meet him? Why couldn’t George come and do some work? Why couldn’t he have got the day off
column5: and come down with us? Bank be blowed! What good was he at the bank?"|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 03:30|"half past three"|"We reached Sunbury lock at half past three. The river is sweetly pretty just there before you come to the gates
column2: and the backwater is charming; but don’t attempt to row up it."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 06:30|"half-past six"|"I remember being terribly upset once up the river (in a figurative sense
column2: I mean). I was out with a young lady – cousin on my mother’s side – and we were pulling down to Goring. It was rather late
column3: and we were anxious to get in – at least she was anxious to get in. It was half-past six when we reached Benson’s lock
column4: and dusk was drawing on
column5: and she began to get excited then. She said she must be in to supper. I said it was a thing I felt I wanted to be in at
column6: too; and I drew out a map I had with me to see exactly how far it was. I saw it was just a mile and a half to the next lock – Wallingford – and five on from there to Cleeve."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 07:00|seven|"‘Oh
column2: it’s all right!’ I said. ‘We’ll be through the next lock before seven
column3: and then there is only one more’; and I settled down and pulled steadily away."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap > 10:00|"past ten"|"Then I began to get nervous myself. I looked again at the map. There was Wallingford lock
column2: clearly marked
column3: a mile and a half below Benson’s. It was a good
column4: reliable map; and
column5: besides
column6: I recollected the lock myself. I had been through it twice. Where were we? What had happened to us? I began to think it must be all a dream
column7: and that I was really asleep in bed
column8: and should wake up in a minute
column9: and be told it was past ten."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 07:30|"half past seven"|"Harris and I began to think that Bell Weir lock must have been done away with after the same manner. George had towed us up to Staines
column2: and we had taken the boat from there
column3: and it seemed that we were dragging fifty tons after us
column4: and were walking forty miles. It was half past seven when we were through
column5: and we all got in
column6: and sculled up close to the left bank
column7: looking out for a spot to haul up in."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 22:00|"ten that night"|"We turned in at ten that night
column2: and I thought I should sleep well
column3: being tired; but I didn’t. As a rule
column4: I undress and put my head on the pillow
column5: and then somebody bangs at the door
column6: and says it is half past eight; but
column7: tonight
column8: everything seemed against me; the novelty of it all
column10: the cramped position (I was lying with my feet under one seat
column12: the sound of the lapping water round the boat
column13: and the wind among the branches
column14: kept me restless and disturbed."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 08:30|"half past eight"|"We turned in at ten that night
column2: and I thought I should sleep well
column3: being tired; but I didn’t. As a rule
column4: I undress and put my head on the pillow
column5: and then somebody bangs at the door
column6: and says it is half past eight; but
column7: tonight
column8: everything seemed against me; the novelty of it all
column10: the cramped position (I was lying with my feet under one seat
column12: the sound of the lapping water round the boat
column13: and the wind among the branches
column14: kept me restless and disturbed."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"I woke at six the next morning; and found George awake too. We both turned round
column2: and tried to go to sleep again
column3: but we could not. Had there been any particular reason why we should not have gone to sleep again
column4: but have got up and dressed then and there
column5: we should have dropped off while we were looking at our watches
column6: and have slept till ten. As there was no earthly necessity for our getting up under another two hours at the very least
column7: and our getting up at that time was an utter absurdity
column8: it was only in keeping with the natural cussedness of things in general that we should both feel that lying down for five minutes more would be death to us."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 10:00|ten|"I woke at six the next morning; and found George awake too. We both turned round
column2: and tried to go to sleep again
column3: but we could not. Had there been any particular reason why we should not have gone to sleep again
column4: but have got up and dressed then and there
column5: we should have dropped off while we were looking at our watches
column6: and have slept till ten. As there was no earthly necessity for our getting up under another two hours at the very least
column7: and our getting up at that time was an utter absurdity
column8: it was only in keeping with the natural cussedness of things in general that we should both feel that lying down for five minutes more would be death to us."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 08:15|"quarter past eight"|"George said that the same kind of thing
column2: only worse
column3: had happened to him some eighteen months ago
column4: when he was lodging by himself in the house of a certain Mrs Gippings. He said his watch went wrong one evening
column5: and stopped at a quarter past eight. He did not know this at the time because
column6: for some reason or other
column7: he forgot to wind it up when he went to bed (an unusual occurrence with him)
column8: and hung it up over his pillow without ever looking at the thing."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 08:15|"quarter past eight"|"It was in the winter when this happened
column2: very near the shortest day
column3: and a week of fog into the bargain
column4: so the fact that it was still very dark when George woke in the morning was no guide to him as to the time. He reached up
column5: and hauled down his watch. It was a quarter past eight."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 08:15|"quarter past eight"|"Whether the shaking it had received in being thrown down on the bed had started it
column2: or how it was
column3: George could not say
column4: but certain it was that from a quarter past eight it had begun to go
column5: and now pointed to twenty minutes to nine."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 08:40|"twenty minutes to nine"|"Whether the shaking it had received in being thrown down on the bed had started it
column2: or how it was
column3: George could not say
column4: but certain it was that from a quarter past eight it had begun to go
column5: and now pointed to twenty minutes to nine."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 08:55|"five minutes to nine"|"At length he reached Holborn. Not a shutter was down! Not a bus was about! There were three men in sight
column2: one of whom was a policeman; a market-cart full of cabbages
column3: and a dilapidated-looking cab. George pulled out his watch and looked at it; it was five minutes to nine! He stood still and counted his pulse. He stooped down and felt his legs. Then
column4: with his watch still in his hand
column5: he went up to the policeman
column6: and asked him if he knew what time it was."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap ~ 03:00|"gone three"|"‘But it’s only gone three!’ said George in an injured tone
column2: when it had finished."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 04:00|"four o’clock in the morning"|"Of course
column2: this conduct made the force only more distrustful of him than ever
column3: and they would come and rout him out and ask him what he was doing there; and when he answered Nothing
column4: he had merely come out for a stroll (it was then four o’clock in the morning)
column5: they looked as though they did not believe him
column6: and two plain-clothes constables came home with him to see if he really did live where he had said he did. They saw him go in with his key
column7: and then they took up a position opposite and watched his house."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 07:30|"half past seven"|"He was in a morbidly nervous state by this time
column2: and he pictured the trial
column3: and his trying to explain the circumstances to the jury
column4: and nobody believing him
column5: and his being sentenced to twenty years’ penal servitude
column6: and his mother dying of a broken heart. So he gave up trying to get breakfast
column7: and wrapped himself up in his overcoat
column8: and sat in the easy-chair till Mrs G. came down at half past seven."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 12:00|noon|"It is noon
column2: and we and all the people have been waiting patient for many an hour
column3: and the rumour has run round that slippery John has again escaped from the Barons’ grasp
column4: and has stolen away from Duncroft Hall with his mercenaries at his heels
column5: and will soon be doing other work than signing charters for his people’s liberty."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 22:00|"ten o’clock at night"|"After you pass Old Windsor
column2: the river is somewhat uninteresting
column3: and does not become itself again until you are nearing Boveney. George and I towed up past the Home Park
column4: which stretches along the right bank from Albert to Victoria Bridge; and as we were passing Datchet
column5: George asked me if I remembered our first trip up the river
column6: and when we landed at Datchet at ten o’clock at night
column7: and wanted to go to bed."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"The Cistercian monks
column2: whose abbey stood there in the thirteenth century
column3: wore no clothes but rough tunics and cowls
column4: and ate no flesh
column5: nor fish
column6: nor eggs. They lay upon straw
column7: and they rose at midnight to mass. They spent the day in labour
column9: and prayer; and over all their lives there fell a silence
column11: for no one spoke."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap < 11:00|"nearly eleven o’clock"|"Henley was getting ready for the regatta
column2: and was full of bustle. We met a goodish number of men we knew about the town
column3: and in their pleasant company the time slipped by somewhat quickly; so that it was nearly eleven o’clock before we set off on our four-mile walk home – as we had learned to call our little craft by this time."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 23:45|"quarter to twelve"|"We struck the tow-path at length
column2: and that made us happy; because prior to this we had not been sure whether we were walking towards the river or away from it
column3: and when you are tired and want to go to bed
column4: uncertainties like that worry you. We passed Shiplake as the clock was striking the quarter to twelve; and then George said
column5: thoughtfully:"|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: > 00:00|"past midnight"|"The case was becoming serious. It was now past midnight. The hotels at Shiplake and Henley would be crammed; and we could not go round
column2: knocking up cottagers and householders in the middle of the night
column3: to know if they let apartments! George suggested walking back to Henley and assaulting a policeman
column4: and so getting a night’s lodging in the station-house. But then there was the thought
column5: ‘Suppose he only hits us back and refuses to lock us up!’"|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap ~ 10:00|"about ten"|"We woke late the next morning
column2: and
column3: at Harris’s earnest desire
column4: partook of a plain breakfast
column5: with ‘non dainties’. Then we cleaned up
column6: and put everything straight (a continual labour
column7: which was beginning to afford me a pretty clear insight into a question that had often posed me – namely
column8: how a woman with the work of only one house on her hands
column9: manages to pass away her time)
column12: set out on what we had determined should be a good day’s journey."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 04:30|"four hours and a half"|"What between tipping the man who had brought us home
column2: and paying for the broken sculls
column3: and for having been out four hours and a half
column4: it cost us a pretty considerable number of weeks’ pocket-money
column5: that sail. But we learned experience
column6: and they say that it is always cheap at any price."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 03:40|"three forty"|"So
column2: eventually he made one final arrangement with himself
column3: which he has religiously held to ever since
column4: and that was to count each fish that he caught as ten
column5: and to assume ten to begin with. For example
column6: if he did not catch any fish at all
column7: then he said he had caught ten fish – you could never catch less than ten fish by his system; that was the foundation of it. Then
column8: if by any chance he really did catch one fish
column10: while two fish would count thirty
column12: and so on."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 08:30|"half past eight"|"We were up early the next morning
column2: as we wanted to be in Oxford by the afternoon. It is surprising how early one can get up
column3: when camping out. One does not yearn for ‘just another five minutes’ nearly so much
column4: lying wrapped up in a rug on the boards of a boat
column5: with a Gladstone bag for a pillow
column6: as one does in a feather bed. We had finished breakfast
column7: and were through Clifton lock by half past eight."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap ~ 00:30|"about half past twelve"|"We passed through Iffley lock at about half past twelve
column2: and then
column3: having tidied up the boat and made all ready for landing
column4: we set to work on our last mile."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: 05:00|"five a.m."|"There being nothing else to do
column2: we went to bed – that is
column3: we undressed ourselves
column4: and tossed about at the bottom of the boat for some three or four hours. After which
column5: we managed to get some fitful slumber until five a.m.
column6: when we all got up and had breakfast."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap ~ 04:00|"about four o’clock"|"At about four o’clock we began to discuss our arrangements for the evening. We were a little past Goring then
column2: and we decided to paddle on to Pangbourne
column3: and put up there for the night."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 06:30|"half past six"|"We sat and mused on the prospect. We should be in at Pangbourne by five. We should finish our dinner at
column2: say
column3: half past six. After that we could walk about the village in the pouring rain until bedtime; or we could sit in a dimly lit bar-parlour and read the almanac."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 09:00|nine|"We had deceived the boatman at Pangbourne. We had not had the face to tell him that we were running away from the rain. We had left the boat
column2: and all it contained
column3: in his charge
column4: with instructions that it was to be ready for us at nine the next morning. If
column5: we said – if anything unforeseen should happen
column6: preventing our return
column7: we would write to him."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 07:00|seven|"We reached Paddington at seven
column2: and drove direct to the restaurant I have before described
column3: where we partook of a light meal
column4: left Montmorency
column5: together with suggestions for a supper to be ready at half past ten
column6: and then continued our way to Leicester Square."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"

column1: ap 10:30|"half past ten"|"We reached Paddington at seven
column2: and drove direct to the restaurant I have before described
column3: where we partook of a light meal
column4: left Montmorency
column5: together with suggestions for a supper to be ready at half past ten
column6: and then continued our way to Leicester Square."|"Three Men in a Boat"|"Jerome K. Jerome"
